title.narrative: IR6: HUMAN POLICY DEV & TOOLS, SUPPORT

description.narrative: UNICEF's capacity to respond to complex humanitarian situations and emergencies strengthened through the development and dissemination of consistent, practiical and applicable humanitarian policies, technical and strategic guidance products and tools which are informed by global developments, inter-agency policy discussions, lessons learnt and best practices with COs support to operationalise those policies and guidance, and through a sustained positioning of UNICEF as a voice in humanitarian policy debates and on advocacy on children's and women's rights in global fora., which contributes to Prevention And Response Services For Violence Against Children, Technical Excellence In Policy And Programmes. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Evaluations, Research And Data, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Timely, Effective and Reliable Humantarian Action Undertaken

HSS - Risk informed programming including climate resilience disaster and conflict
HSS - public finance management for Health

Public health emergencies, including disease outbreaks

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: UNICEF's capacity to respond to complex humanitarian situations and emergencies strengthened through the development anddissemination of consistent, practiical and applicable humanitarian policies, technical and strategic guidance products and toolswhich are informed by global developments, inter-agency policy discussions, lessons learnt and best practices; with COs support tooperationalise those policies and guidance, and through a sustained positioning of UNICEF as a voice in humanitarian policy debatesand on advocacy on children's and women's rights in global fora.

of UNICEF COs receiving direct support through missions or remote guidance to develop and implement a systematic approach to national capacity development for achieving prioritized CCCs and experiences systematically documented

baseline.value: 2 UNICEF country offices have received direct support from EMOPS. 4 others will receive direct support in 2011.Technical Guidance Note with toolkit for CD for CCCs completed in 2010 and disseminated in 2011. Online toolkit and user support being rolled-out in 2011

title.narrative: of UNICEF COs receiving support to mainstream gender into humanitarian response , good practices in gender mainstreaming and HRBA in emergencies documented and disseminated, humanitarian components of the UNICEF gender policy implemented

baseline.value: 5 pilot countries + some new emergencies + 9 COs from 2009 receive support to ensure that response plans mainstream gender and adopt a human rights approach,

title.narrative: of Country Offices receiving support on relevant aspects of working in high risk environments (IHL, IHRL, engagement with NSEs, programme criticality, humanitarian principles, civil-military cooperation, etc.), of COs/ROs/HQ divisions that have received training, policy advice, briefs on context specific issues per year

baseline.value: Direct support on issues related to working in high risk environments is provided on an ad hoc basis (e.g. no systematic monitoring in place) in 8 situations per year at minimum. New guidance developed for aspects of working in high risk environments (NSEs and remote programming in 2011, programme criticality TBC), 4 COs/ROs/HQ divisions on average receive training, policy advice, briefs on context specific issues provided to 3 humanitarian situations per year,

title.narrative: Percentage of humanitarian inter-agency policies (including IASC, security-related, ISG) which adequately reflect UNICEF's key mandate and operational concerns, of UNICEF policies, guidance and tools which are aligned with inter-agency policies, of COs and ROs that receive support in applying the principles and policies that underpin humanitarian reform and other inter-agency humanitarian policies

baseline.value: High % of humanitarian inter-agency policies are consistent with UNICEF organizational policies and can be implemented adequately by the organization. All key UNICEF humanitarian policies, guidance and tools reflect inter-agency policies. On average 2 COs per year receive direct support, indirect support provided via dissemination of policies, guidance and tools

title.narrative: Highly visible and high quality contribution by UNICEF [through EMOPS] in Security Council and other high level institutional mechanisms concerning CAAC, SVC, Protection of Civilians, among others, of COs that receive information about developments related to PoC (CAAC, SVC and other protection issues as well as R2P) in UN policy, other inter-agency fora, and in the Security Council

baseline.value: High quality inputs to the SCWG on CAAC, ensuring strong links between thematic SRSG mandates and in-country action via UNICEF COs, and tracking the implementation of SCWG recommendations, 20 Country Offices are regularly kept informed of developments related to PoC (CAAC, SVC and other protection issues as well as R2P) in UN policy, other inert-agency for a, and in the Security Council, child protection issues continue to receive considerable attention within overall PoC debates and in country-

title.narrative: Messaging on equity and emergencies-humanitarian situations receives high visibility within UNICEF and outside, elements of an approach to equity in emergency response and humanitarian actions are identified and support provided to COs in strengthening programmes

baseline.value: Humanitarian situations have not received any specific attention in UNICEF documents on equity, except for the Q+A, there is not clarity on what an equity approach means in emergencies or in humanitarian situations

title.narrative: of humanitarian situations where UNICEF strategy and programme is informed by best practices and lessons learnt, proportion of major emergency response humanitarian response for which lessons are documented and avaiiable to the organization, of HAR countries that implement a humanitarian performance monitoring system

baseline.value: Lessons learned from emergency response and humanitarian action in an average of 2 situations per year are systematically documented, other lessons are collated in a database, lessons are provided on a just in time basis to all major emergencies since early 2010. Humanitarian performance monitoring system still under development, has been applied in 2 humanitarian situations,

title.narrative: Revised CCCs are understood by all HAR countries and used as the basis for preparedness, response planning and reporting

baseline.value: Tools are available to COs and ROs to ensure training and adequate application of the CCCs
